document.docAuthor: Rentz, Dcf, Su, You Ning & Ueshima, Norihiro
document.docTitle: Ganiagraecia karwinia Rentz, Su & Ueshima, 2021, Gen. et sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Studies in Australian Tettigoniidae: New short-winged Agraeciini from Australia (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae; Conocephalinae; Agraeciini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Studies in Australian Tettigoniidae: New short-winged Agraeciini from Australia (Orthoptera: Tettigoniidae; Conocephalinae; Agraeciini)

paragraph.emphasis: Rentz, Su and Ueshima Gen. et sp. nov.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype male.
( In alcohol) 1. “ 25.26S 152.56E Mt. Tibrogargan (parking area), Glass House Mts. Qld.
15 August 1985
D. C. F. Rentz , R . Chiang, Stop 12”. 2. “collected as nymph, matured in laboratory 16.x.85”. 3. “ D. C. F. Rentz , Cytol. prep. 85-29”. 3. “Song recorded S-363”. 4. “ ANIC database #14008749”
. Holotype in alcohol in Australian National Insect Collection, Canberra.
Paratypes . Queensland .
25 o 26’S

20.x.1985
; Cytol prep. 85-17, ANIC )
.

Type locality. The type locality is a rather open woodland with many Grass Trees,
Xanthorrhoea sp.
, tall eucalypts and a dense undercover of herbs and grasses. The katydids were abundant in the lush weedy vegetation.

tableCitation.captionText: TABLE 2. Measurements (in mm) of Short-winged agraeciine species. Localities are notational. See text for full locality data.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Known only from the Glasshouse Mts., Queensland ( Map 4 ).

Habitat. Common in open woodland vegetated by tall eucalypts and
Xanthorrhoea
.
Seasonal occurrence. Adults found in mid spring.
Stridulatory file. File very distinctive ( Figs 20C, D ). Proximal portion with approximately 20 large teeth, decreasing in size and approximately 24-26 minute teeth on a raised swelling.

10 Karwin is an aboriginal word for Grass Trees,
Xanthorrhoea species.

Discussion. This species appears to be endemic to the Glasshouse Mts. Its appearance and habitat preference is similar to that of
Australiagraecia species
but morphologically very different.
